channel.title: 华尔街日报热门
channel.description: 用中文浏览华尔街日报热门报道

item.title: It’s not just the accent: Ted Lasso’s pop-culture references come so fast and furious that you’ve probably missed a lot. We’re here to help. https://t.co/tDsFw6xTjY
Take an early look at the front page of The Wall Street Journal https://t.co/5xQPDPcm8q https://t.co/AUSGROYKD3

Football coach and commentator John Madden, who died Tuesday at age 85, made a complex sport sound like backyard fun. That’s a small part of Madden’s deep legacy, writes @JasonGay https://t.co/JXyMTddkvk
The arrests of seven people linked to a popular Hong Kong pro-democracy news site dealt a new blow to press freedom in the city https://t.co/vyvYp3OgXm
The mummy of the Egyptian pharoah Amenhotep I, who lived more than 3,500 years ago, has been “digitally unwrapped,” thanks to CT scans https://t.co/5Pk3urp1WU
From @WSJopinion: Unlike his 2020 campaign message, Biden now tells governors that there’s “no federal solution” to Covid. It’s the job of the states. https://t.co/XxJEhTvc2J
Elon Musk has converted more than 1.5 million options into stock and sold more than 934,000 shares to cover associated taxes https://t.co/NrRNjbqgNx
During a 50-year career in which the game he loved changed so dramatically, legendary broadcaster John Madden enjoyed a popularity that was one of the few constants https://t.co/SDZnIv8Q6l
Harry Reid, the former Democratic Senate Majority leader who led during the Obama presidency, has died at age 82 https://t.co/fCFya3AYNc
The surge in Covid-19 cases could disrupt jury deliberations in British socialite Ghislaine Maxwell’s sex-trafficking trial, a federal judge warned Tuesday https://t.co/3XVskucqSb
Why Mark Zuckerberg may be wrong about the metaverse as the inevitable next paradigm shift in the digital world https://t.co/LBdYWTcgVb
John Madden, Hall of Fame Oakland Raiders coach, longtime broadcaster and name behind the blockbuster football videogame, has died at 85 https://t.co/w5ZRYg17O2

The U.S. touted female Afghan service members as a flagship accomplishment of its effort to empower women in Afghanistan. But almost all of them have been left behind, fearing for their lives. https://t.co/lP8RqJUr0T

“The toxic environment has been building for a long, long time before Jan. 6, but Jan. 6, just blew it up in flames.” Fallout from the attack on the Capitol fractured House relationships, further undercutting comity. https://t.co/jqwewH4Db4
From @WSJopinion: Joe Biden is running his presidency as if he were still a senator. That's a problem, writes @wjmcgurn. https://t.co/76rkiuhXXU
Where in the world is Elon Musk? Despite selling his real estate, he can be found in a colossal, waterfront Austin mansion https://t.co/0k8VK1j7ft
People who test positive for Covid-19 and don't have symptoms can isolate for five days instead of 10 the CDC has said https://t.co/Q2ejYDUk4K
The mummy of the Egyptian pharoah Amenhotep I, who lived more than 3,500 years ago, has been “digitally unwrapped,” thanks to CT scans https://t.co/VlICi6FH4k
An NYU grad has more than $160,000 in student loans and struggles to land a job in her field. So she sells her eggs. https://t.co/9EDNBXmHf9
The owners of a tech incubator in Rome are resurrecting a hydropower plant designed more than 125 years ago by Albert Einstein’s father https://t.co/K9Pt5pDDvG

From @WSJopinion: If Congress is truly concerned about the Communist Chinese threat, cutting off the flow of Wall Street dollars that is funding Chinese tech growth should be its highest legislative priority, writes @robertcobrien https://t.co/UBv0hYkJfr
U.S. officials have cut the number of days that they recommend people should isolate for after being infected with Covid-19 https://t.co/EVsEzAEjOh

Edward O. Wilson, the pioneering Harvard biologist who argued for a new vision of human nature in “Sociobiology” and warned against the decline of ecosystems, has died. He was 92. https://t.co/JuxY31LMRB
From @WSJopinion: Joe Manchin has no reason to apologize for asking that a bill to transform America be subject to regular Congressional order https://t.co/sJUSQQGpuT
From @WSJopinion: Vice President Harris says the main threats to U.S. national security are climate change and American democracy. Can someone help her out? https://t.co/MV7yfTs4dE
Pandemic’s hidden toll: millions in U.K. await treatment, but not for Covid-19 https://t.co/ppycPt5IzF

Pope Francis appointed Sister Nathalie Becquart as the first woman to serve as an undersecretary of the Synod of Bishops earlier this year. “I felt as if I was at the beginning of a new adventure, called to go into the deep sea,” she said. https://t.co/3ECYUaxrrS
Bees do it. Can we? When a dangerous, virus-carrying parasite enters the hive, bees spread out and foil its transmission. https://t.co/g0b1CIwnmv
Former workers of AT&T will see life insurance that was promised to them, in some cases decades ago, cut back unless they die by Dec. 31 https://t.co/gDfb6fBmd4
Take an early look at the front page of The Wall Street Journal https://t.co/NKrus9IHJM https://t.co/1ry7Rmhrs3
New research shows that just 0.01% of bitcoin holders control 27% of the currency in circulation https://t.co/r4pO4JelAE
TikTok has become the new “Dr. Google” for teens, and some are diagnosing themselves with rare mental disorders. “It really messed with my head,” an 18-year-old said. https://t.co/hV8dZwDBHU
As thousands of Venezuelan women leave their collapsing country in search of a better life, many are lured into sex trafficking https://t.co/kWeR0GsHhK
“It’s like nothing anyone has ever seen before.” Jeff Bezos, Mark Zuckerberg and many others have poured money into Hawaii real estate since the start of the pandemic. https://t.co/sD5bHaGsQT
The owners of a tech incubator in Rome are resurrecting a hydropower plant designed more than 125 years ago by Albert Einstein’s father https://t.co/jdFfVmByd4
Doctors around the country say TikTok is driving an increase in teen patients convinced they have rare mental disorders: "It can be tricky when there’s a strong clinging to a particular diagnosis."
Former workers of AT&T will see life insurance that was promised to them, in some cases decades ago, cut back unless they die by Dec. 31 https://t.co/CVvrvXQt8B
What Turkey’s currency crisis has to do with the global supply chain of Nutella https://t.co/35zrX5Ubym
No one in Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida’s government will attend the Beijing Olympics. But Tokyo isn’t calling it a boycott. https://t.co/BqxmTMSdNi
The expert ham sniffer of Spain smells 800 hams a day during the Christmas season. He is strained, he said, “at the limit of human possibility.” https://t.co/lMigsQHuKX
Former Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey has triggered a debate among tech stalwarts over how decentralized the future internet may be https://t.co/xaF8Hpa7wZ
Anglican archbishop Desmond Tutu, who has died at age 90, led a global campaign to end South Africa’s racist policies and helped in healing the nation’s wounds https://t.co/S2OZRM0D25
An NYU grad has more than $160,000 in student loans and struggles to land a job in her field. So she sells her eggs. https://t.co/yEr33NyiSu
One hundred times as powerful as Hubble, the James Webb telescope could show the face of Abraham Lincoln on a penny from 24 miles away https://t.co/00uBHMxde2
An attack by Myanmar’s military killed dozens of people, including children, in a part of the country where resistance groups have been fighting the junta https://t.co/TwJMS26hgn
How the Taliban head-faked the world: “Monopoly of power is a story of failure,” a spokesman said—six months before the group seized Kabul and monopolized all power https://t.co/YSztGj5teT
In a city where Russia triumphed 300 years ago, Ukrainians are mobilizing to resist another Russian leader, Vladimir Putin https://t.co/NB1v459nvY
The owners of a tech incubator in Rome are resurrecting a hydropower plant designed more than 125 years ago by Albert Einstein’s father https://t.co/URV4XzqyDU
At least $100 billion has been stolen from Covid-19 relief programs designed to help individuals and businesses harmed by the pandemic, the U.S. Secret Service said https://t.co/mV4uiCOjKv
Desmond Tutu, an Anglican archbishop who led a global campaign to end South Africa’s racist policies and then helped in healing the nation’s wounds, has died at 90 https://t.co/1mUZANVsI9
